value: aava_1.0_score
description

The two metadata versions represent the same conceptual workflow model with significant structural evolution and moderate semantic preservation. AAVA 2.0 introduces enhanced schema organization while maintaining core business logic.
Core workflow concept preserved: DI_DataSpecs_Modelupdates_SN workflow maintains same business purpose across versions.
Agent functionality semantically equivalent: All three agents (Technical Specification, Delta Model Changes, Functional Test Cases) preserve their core responsibilities.
Model deployment evolution: gpt-4 to gpt-4.1 represents version upgrade maintaining semantic compatibility.
Root structure reorganized: workflowId/workflowName flattened to workFlowDetail object with id/name properties.
Agent container renamed: 'nodes' array changed to 'workflowAgents' array, improving semantic clarity.
Agent property restructuring: agentName->name, model->modelDeploymentName, tools->toolReferences with structural changes.
Tool reference mechanism changed: String array tools replaced with empty toolReferences arrays, indicating architectural shift.
Workflow identifier: workflowId (1594) mapped to workFlowDetail.id (2147) - different values indicate separate instances.
Workflow naming: workflowName mapped to workFlowDetail.name with consistent value preservation.
Agent naming convention: agentName with underscores changed to name with spaces for readability.
Model specification: model field renamed to modelDeploymentName with version upgrade (gpt-4 -> gpt-4.1).
Workflow ID type preserved: Integer type maintained across versions (1594 -> 2147).
Agent ID introduction: New agentId field added in v2.0 providing unique agent identification.
Tool constraint modification: Required tools array in v1.0 replaced with optional empty toolReferences in v2.0.
Tool definitions removed: DI_Github_File_Writer_Z tool reference present in v1.0 but absent in v2.0 toolReferences.
Task structure flattened: Complex task object with description/expectedOutput in v1.0 simplified to description-only in v2.0.
Metadata completeness degradation: Loss of expectedOutput specifications reduces governance quality in v2.0.
Tool traceability lost: Explicit tool mappings in v1.0 replaced with empty arrays reducing operational transparency.
Schema version evolution: Structure indicates major version upgrade with breaking changes to client systems.
Backward compatibility risk: Field renames and structural changes may break existing integrations.
JSON syntax validation: Well-formed JSON with consistent structure and valid data types.
Internal consistency: All agent references, tool mappings, and task structures are logically consistent.
Data integrity: Workflow ID, agent names, and tool references maintain referential integrity.
JSON syntax validation: Well-formed JSON with enhanced object structure and valid data types.
Internal consistency: Agent IDs, workflow details, and model deployments are logically consistent.
Minor inconsistency: Empty toolReferences arrays suggest incomplete tool integration specification.
Integration breaking changes: Structural modifications require updates to all dependent systems and APIs.
Tool reference gaps: Missing tool specifications in v2.0 may cause runtime failures in agent execution.
Metadata governance degradation: Reduced specification detail may impact system documentation and maintenance.
Tool integration unclear: Empty toolReferences arrays create ambiguity about actual tool dependencies.
Version mapping uncertainty: Different workflow IDs (1594 vs 2147) unclear if same logical workflow.
Model upgrade path: Clear evolution from gpt-4 to gpt-4.1 across all agents indicates planned upgrade.
Naming standardization: Consistent move from underscore to space-separated naming improves readability.
Architectural evolution: Shift from simple arrays to structured objects indicates maturing metadata model.
